title: 105_hr2408
content: The "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students by offering productive activities during after school hours. The findings in the "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" highlight the increased social risks faced by today's youth, with students spending more unsupervised time alone. Law enforcement data shows that youth aged 12-17 are most vulnerable to violence between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m., and academic failure consequences are more severe than ever. The goals of the Act include increasing academic success, improving students' skills, promoting safe environments, preparing for workforce participation, and providing alternatives to negative activities. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "school" refers to public kindergarten, elementary, or secondary schools. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. SEC. 6. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Secretary can award grants to schools for carrying out activities in section 7(a). SEC. 7. AUTHORIZED ACTIVITIES; REQUIREMENTS. Each school receiving a grant under this Act must conduct at least 2 of the following activities: mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training. Additionally, schools may choose to implement drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation activities. A school must provide activities after regular school hours, reflecting specific needs of the population, in a designated location. Encouraged to request volunteers from business and academic sectors. To support activities after school hours, schools are encouraged to seek volunteers from the business and academic communities, request computer equipment donations, and collaborate with State and local park agencies to avoid duplication of efforts. SEC. 8. APPLICATIONS. Each school seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary, detailing how the goals of the Act will be met, evidence of collaboration, administration plans, and utilization of activities. The application for a grant must demonstrate collaboration, administration plans, funding sources, and a plan for obtaining non-Federal funding. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2002.
